E6C69B60DFE50131FCE968A86D17958E.description: Understanding that most plant and animal species are threatened or endangered today due to habitat loss or change.

E6C64860DFE50131FCE868A86D17958E.description: Understanding that the original sources of all material goods are natural resources and that the conserving and recycling of natural resources is a form of stewardship;

E6C5F7D0DFE50131FCE768A86D17958E.description: Identifying ways in which humans have altered their environment, both in positive and negative ways, either for themselves or for other living things;

E6C5AC80DFE50131FCE668A86D17958E.description: Understanding the components of a food chain;

E6C55C10DFE50131FCE568A86D17958E.description: Understanding that an "ecosystem" is made of living and non-living components;

E6C506D0DFE50131FCE468A86D17958E.description: In Grades K-4, what students know and are able to do includes:

E6C4C300DFE50131FCE368A86D17958E.description: In learning environmental science, students will develop an appreciation of the natural environment, learn the importance of environmental quality, and acquire a sense of stewardship. As consumers and citizens, they will be able to recognize how our personal, professional, and political actions affect the natural world.

comments: Environmental education is a process aimed at the development of a literate citizenry which is aware of and shows concern for the total environment and its associated problems. This goal will be met by developing the knowledge, attitudes, motivation, commitment, and skills to work individually and collectively toward the solutions of current problems and the prevention of new ones.

E6C432A0DFE50131FCE168A86D17958E.description: Understanding that knowledge of the earth as well as of the universe is gained through space exploration.

E6C3CF70DFE50131FCE068A86D17958E.description: Understanding that the sun, a star, is a source of heat and light energy and identifying its effects upon the earth;

E6C37A50DFE50131FCDF68A86D17958E.description: Modeling changes that occur because of the rotation of the earth (alternation of night and day) and the revolution of the earth around the sun;

E6C32860DFE50131FCDE68A86D17958E.description: Observing and recording the changing appearances and positions of the moon in the sky at night and determining the monthly pattern of lunar change;

E6C2E740DFE50131FCDD68A86D17958E.description: Demonstrating how the relationship of the earth, moon, and sun causes eclipses and moon phases;

E6C2A590DFE50131FCDC68A86D17958E.description: Observing and describing the characteristics of objects in the sky;

E6C263E0DFE50131FCDB68A86D17958E.description: Objects in the sky, which include:

E6C220B0DFE50131FCDA68A86D17958E.description: Investigating fossils and describing how they provide evidence about plants and animals that lived long ago and the environment in which they lived;

E6C1DD90DFE50131FCD968A86D17958E.description: Observing and describing variations in soiL;

E6C18E70DFE50131FCD868A86D17958E.description: Observing and communicating that rocks are composed of various substances;

E6C13D90DFE50131FCD768A86D17958E.description: Investigating, observing, measuring, and describing changes in daily weather patterns and phenomena;

E6C0FA20DFE50131FCD668A86D17958E.description: Investigating, observing, and describing how water changes from one form to another and interacts with the atmosphere;

E6C0B400DFE50131FCD568A86D17958E.description: Understanding that approximately three-fourths of the earth's surface is covered with water and how this condition affects weather patterns and climates;

E6C06DC0DFE50131FCD468A86D17958E.description: Understanding that earth materials are rocks, minerals, and soils;

E6C02720DFE50131FCD368A86D17958E.description: Properties of earth materials, which include:

E6BFD530DFE50131FCD268A86D17958E.description: In Grades K-4, what students know and are able to do includes:

E6BF8850DFE50131FCD168A86D17958E.description: The students will develop an understanding of the properties of earth materials, the structure of the earth system, the earth's history, and the earth's place in the universe.

comments: In order to develop a basic understanding of our world, it is essential for students to reflect upon the structure, order, and origin of the universe. This understanding occurs gradually over time as students observe, investigate, model, describe, and find patterns in a changing world. As humans modify their surroundings, they must reflect upon the consequences that these changes will bring. Scientific knowledge about environmental forces and resources will provide a rich topic for critical thinking by students to analyze the effects of their choices on the world.

E6BEE300DFE50131FCCF68A86D17958E.description: Observing animals and plants and describing interaction or interdependence.

E6BE8FF0DFE50131FCCE68A86D17958E.description: Describing how the features of some plants and animals enable them to live in specific habitats;

E6BE2120DFE50131FCCD68A86D17958E.description: Examining the habitats of plants and animals and determining how basic needs are met within each habitat;

E6BDB390DFE50131FCCC68A86D17958E.description: Organisms and their environments, which include:

E6BD6010DFE50131FCCB68A86D17958E.description: Observing, recording, and graphing student growth over time using a variety of quantitative measures (height, weight, linear measure of feet and hands, etc.);

E6BD1D00DFE50131FCCA68A86D17958E.description: Observing and recording how the offspring of plants and animals are similar to their parents;

E6BCD8F0DFE50131FCC968A86D17958E.description: Observing, comparing, and grouping plants and animals according to likenesses and/or differences;

E6BC8210DFE50131FCC868A86D17958E.description: Observing and describing the life cycles of some plants and animals;

E6BC3E20DFE50131FCC768A86D17958E.description: Life cycles of organisms, which include:

E6BBFB60DFE50131FCC668A86D17958E.description: Recognizing the food groups necessary to maintain a healthy body;

E6BBB770DFE50131FCC568A86D17958E.description: Locating major human body organs and describing their functions;

E6BB7390DFE50131FCC468A86D17958E.description: Recognizing that there is great diversity among organisms;

E6BB2E60DFE50131FCC368A86D17958E.description: Locating and comparing major plant and animal structures and their functions;

E6BAE580DFE50131FCC268A86D17958E.description: Distinguishing between living and nonliving things;

E6BA8D10DFE50131FCC168A86D17958E.description: Identifying the needs of plants and animals, based on age-appropriate recorded observations;

E6B9E3F0DFE50131FCBF68A86D17958E.description: In Grades K-4, what students know and are able to do includes:

E6B98F70DFE50131FCBE68A86D17958E.description: The students will become aware of the characteristics and life cycles of organisms and understand their relationships to each other and to their environment.

comments: As investigations of the living environment are conducted, the rationales are set to establish further observations, measurements, and classifications of the various life forms. Patterns of similarities and differences within the diversity of life establish the basis for understanding the special relationships among living things in ecosystems.

E6B8D810DFE50131FCBC68A86D17958E.description: Exploring and describing the uses of energy at school, home, and play.

E6B88D50DFE50131FCBB68A86D17958E.description: Exploring and describing simple energy transformations;

E6B82B50DFE50131FCBA68A86D17958E.description: Investigating and communicating that magnetism and gravity can exert forces on objects without touching the objects;

E6B7C1D0DFE50131FCB968A86D17958E.description: Investigating and describing how electricity travels in a circuit;

E6B77A90DFE50131FCB868A86D17958E.description: Investigating and describing different ways heat can be produced and moved from one object to another by conduction;

E6B72BA0DFE50131FCB768A86D17958E.description: Investigating and describing how light travels and what happens when light strikes an object (reflection, refraction, and absorption);

E6B6E7C0DFE50131FCB668A86D17958E.description: Experimenting and communicating how vibrations of objects produce sound and how changing the rate of vibration varies the pitch;

E6B65980DFE50131FCB468A86D17958E.description: Investigating and describing how the motion of an object is related to the strength of the force (pushing or pulling) and the mass of the object;

E6B61540DFE50131FCB368A86D17958E.description: Describing an object's motion by tracing and measuring its position over time;

E6B5CCE0DFE50131FCB268A86D17958E.description: Exploring and recognizing that the position and motion of objects can be changed by pushing or pulling (force) over time;

E6B57B90DFE50131FCB168A86D17958E.description: Observing and describing the position of an object relative to another object or the background;

E6B4DBB0DFE50131FCAF68A86D17958E.description: Creating mixtures and separating them based on differences in properties (salt, sand);

E6B48720DFE50131FCAE68A86D17958E.description: Describing the properties of the different states of matter and identifying the conditions that cause matter to change states;

E6B431A0DFE50131FCAD68A86D17958E.description: Observing and describing the objects by the properties of the materials from which they are made (paper, wood, metal);

E6B3E3C0DFE50131FCAC68A86D17958E.description: Measuring properties of objects using appropriate materials, tools, and technology;

E6B3A120DFE50131FCAB68A86D17958E.description: Observing, describing, and classifying objects by properties (size, weight, shape, color, texture, and temperature);

E6B31840DFE50131FCA968A86D17958E.description: In Grades K-4, what students know and are able to do includes:

E6B2CB50DFE50131FCA868A86D17958E.description: Students will develop an understanding of the characteristics and interrelationships of matter and energy in the physical world.

comments: Exploring the characteristics, forces, and changes in objects and materials encourages students to develop an understanding of the world in which they live to establish a basis for a lifelong study of their world. As students increase their understanding and abilities, they will be able to use more sophisticated qualitative and quantitative methods to construct and analyze information. This study will enable them to make informed decisions based on a better understanding of how things work in the physical world.

E6B20B00DFE50131FCA668A86D17958E.description: Reviewing and asking questions about the results of investigations.

E6B185F0DFE50131FCA468A86D17958E.description: Developing explanations by using observations and experiments;

E6B14120DFE50131FCA368A86D17958E.description: Choosing appropriate equipment and tools to conduct an experiment;

E6B0FBD0DFE50131FCA268A86D17958E.description: Using appropriate experiments depending on the questions to be explored;

E6B0B120DFE50131FCA168A86D17958E.description: Categorizing questions into what is known, what is not known, and what questions need to be explained;

E6AFC110DFE50131FC9E68A86D17958E.description: Communicating observations and experiments in oral and written formats;

E6AF6EC0DFE50131FC9D68A86D17958E.description: Using data, including numbers and graphs, to explain observations and experiments;

E6AF1C00DFE50131FC9C68A86D17958E.description: Employing equipment and tools to gather data and extend the sensory observations;

E6AECE70DFE50131FC9B68A86D17958E.description: Communicating that observations are made with one's senses;

E6AE81E0DFE50131FC9A68A86D17958E.description: Planning and/or designing and conducting a scientific investigation;

E6AE3E10DFE50131FC9968A86D17958E.description: Asking appropriate questions about organisms and events in the environment;

E6ADF860DFE50131FC9868A86D17958E.description: The abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry:

E6ADB200DFE50131FC9768A86D17958E.description: In Grades K-4, what students know and are able to do includes:

E6AD6A50DFE50131FC9668A86D17958E.description: The students will do science by engaging in partial and full inquiries that are within their developmental capabilities.

comments: The process of scientific inquiry involves "asking a question, planning and conducting an investigation, using appropriate tools, mathematics, and techniques, thinking critically and logically about the relationships between evidence and explanations constructing and analyzing alternative explanations, and communicating scientific arguments"
